site_name: Triple R Farms Hattiesburg, LLC Carmen & Miles Smith

citations.narrative:
On November 2nd, 2023 a young child was bitten on the hand by an adult capuchin monkey after the child went under the
public barrier around the monkey enclosure. The bite broke the skin and required medical treatment. The public barrier
surrounding the monkey enclosure consisted of an approximately 4-foot high fence made of 3 lines of rope hanging
between poles, and in the front of the enclosure there is a gate in the barrier that consists of just 1 strand of rope at waist
height. The enclosure has signs posted that instructs patrons not touch the animals.
Insufficient distance and/or barriers between animals and the public may result in unauthorized contact between animals
and members of the public. This contact can result in stress, disease transmission, injuries or even death to animals
and/or visitors. Animals that bite may be subject to mandatory euthanasia in accordance with local or state public health
requirements.
Correct by ensuring that animals are handled so there is minimal risk of harm to the animals and to the public, with
sufficient distance and/or barriers between the animals and the general viewing public as to assure the safety of animals
and the public. Correct by: 11/15/23.

On the night of October 20th, 2023 two juvenile female fennec foxes escaped from their outdoor primary enclosure and
left the property. The upper half of the walls of the primary enclosure consisted wire panels with openings that were 2
inches by 4 inches in size, and it is through these openings that the foxes are thought to have escaped. One fox was
recovered 11 days later at a location about 5 miles away, the second fox has not been recovered or sighted.
Animals that escape from their enclosures may suffer from stress, injury, hunger, thirst, or may die.
Correct by 11/9/2023 by ensuring that enclosures are constructed appropriately for the animals they house, and that they
are maintained in good repair to protect the animals from injury and contain the animals. Corrected prior to the inspection
on 11/8/23.
This inspection and exit interview were conducted with the owner.
n

narrative:
2.131(c)(1)  Critical
   
Handling of animals. 
On November 2nd, 2023 a young child was bitten on the hand by an adult capuchin monkey after the child went under the 
public barrier around the monkey enclosure. The bite broke the skin and required medical treatment. The public barrier 
surrounding the monkey enclosure consisted of an approximately 4-foot high fence made of 3 lines of rope hanging 
between poles, and in the front of the enclosure there is a gate in the barrier that consists of just 1 strand of rope at waist 
height. The enclosure has signs posted that instructs patrons not touch the animals. 
Insufficient distance and/or barriers between animals and the public may result in unauthorized contact between animals 
and members of the public. This contact can result in stress, disease transmission, injuries or even death to animals 
and/or visitors. Animals that bite may be subject to mandatory euthanasia in accordance with local or state public health 
requirements. 
Correct by ensuring that animals are handled so there is minimal risk of harm to the animals and to the public, with 
sufficient distance and/or barriers between the animals and the general viewing public as to assure the safety of animals 
and the public. Correct by: 11/15/23. 
3.125(a)  Critical
   
Facilities, general. 
On the night of October 20th, 2023 two juvenile female fennec foxes escaped from their outdoor primary enclosure and 
left the property. The upper half of the walls of the primary enclosure consisted wire panels with openings that were 2 
inches by 4 inches in size, and it is through these openings that the foxes are thought to have escaped. One fox was 
recovered 11 days later at a location about 5 miles away, the second fox has not been recovered or sighted.  
Animals that escape from their enclosures may suffer from stress, injury, hunger, thirst, or may die.  
Correct by 11/9/2023 by ensuring that enclosures are constructed appropriately for the animals they house, and that they 
are maintained in good repair to protect the animals from injury and contain the animals. Corrected prior to the inspection 
on 11/8/23. 
 
This inspection and exit interview were conducted with the owner.
